author: pcgeek86
body: Steps to reproduce ------------------ 1. Create a vanilla Windows Server 2016 Data Center virtual machine 2. Login to the instance using RDP or PowerShell Remoting over WinRM 3. Open PowerShell Console Host or Integrated Scripting Editor (ISE) 4. Call `Install-Module -Name AWSPowerShell -Scope CurrentUser -Force` Expected behavior ----------------- When installing a PowerShell module, using the standard, built-in `Install-Module` command, the PowerShell module should install successfully, without throwing errors. Actual behavior --------------- Rather than installing successfully, the `Install-Module` PowerShell command throws a nasty error message about code signing. Within the text of the error message, I didn't observe a link to documentation about what code signing is, how to code sign a PowerShell module, or under what circumstances code signing a module is necessary, or who is responsible for doing this. The exception message does indicate adding a parameter called `-SkipPublisherCheck`, but doesn't explain why this is necessary, or if this is even safe to do, from a security standpoint. Security conscious users will not want to arbitrarily disable security policies that were put into place to ensure the integrity of the software that they are installing and executing. ``` PS C:\Users\Administrator> Install-Module -Scope CurrentUser -Name AWSPowerShell -Force; PackageManagement\Install-Package : The version '3.3.32.0' of the module 'AWSPowerShell' being installed is not catalog signed. Ensure that the version '3.3.32.0' of the module 'AWSPowerShell' has the catalog file 'AWSPowerShell.cat' and signed with the same publisher 'CN=VeriSign Class 3 Public Primary Certification Authority - G5, OU="(c) 2006 VeriSign, Inc. - For authorized use only", OU=VeriSign Trust Network, O="VeriSign, Inc.", C=US' as the previously-installed module '3.3.32.0' with version '3.3.23.0' under the directory 'C:\Program Files (x86)\AWS Tools\PowerShell\AWSPowerShell'. If you still want to install or update, use -SkipPublisherCheck parameter. At C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\PowerShellGet\1.0.0.1\PSModule.psm1:1661 char:21 + ... $null = PackageManagement\Install-Package @PSBoundParameters + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ + CategoryInfo : InvalidOperation: (Microsoft.Power....InstallPackage:InstallPackage) [Install-Package], Exception + FullyQualifiedErrorId : ModuleIsNotCatalogSigned,Validate-ModuleAuthenticodeSignature,Microsoft.PowerShell.PackageManagement.Cmdlets.InstallPackage ``` Environment data ---------------- - Windows Server 2016 Data Center Edition - Instance provisioned on Amazon Web Services (AWS) EC2 - Instance exists in dedicated Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) - VPC has Internet Gateway attached - VPC Subnet has full outbound routing to the Internet ```powershell PS C:\Users\Administrator> $PSVersionTable Name Value ---- ----- PSVersion 5.1.14393.206 PSEdition Desktop PSCompatibleVersions {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...} BuildVersion 10.0.14393.206 CLRVersion 4.0.30319.42000 WSManStackVersion 3.0 PSRemotingProtocolVersion 2.3 SerializationVersion 1.1.0.1 ```

comments.body: @pcgeek86 This was a known issue and got resolved with the latest Cumulative Update. Please try again after installing the latest Cumulative Update.
